title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: How to Grill Steak
content: hi I'm welcome to quality needs and today we're going to be talking about how to grill steak not going to do anything fancy you're gonna stick to the basics and we're going to show you how to get the right sear and the right temperature for the steak that you want today I'm going to be using a beef loin New York steak you can use different kind of steak but I want to show you the basics of how to grill it to get it to the temp that you want so first what we're gonna do here is we're gonna show you our steak here you have to be flowing New York State you're going to notice this nice strip of bat that's gonna get the steak itself a lot of flavors and it's gonna keep it nice and juicy a good steak doesn't need a lot of seasoning or marinade so today all I'm using is an olive oil rub as well steak seasoning so what I'm going to do right now is I'm going to take olive oil and rub it into the steak the next step is to take the steak seasoning and to apply it generously to the steak itself what you're gonna want to do is you're gonna want to let you stay sit out in room temperature for around 15 to 20 minutes before you put it onto the grill this is gonna let it cook evenly go outside and turn on your grill too high or around 500-600 degrees and it's going to stay like that for around 15 minutes now we're going to put the steak right onto the grill you go ahead and just close the grill now that the snake is on the grill we're gonna let it cook on one side for four to five minutes afterwards we're gonna flip it over once we flipped it over we're gonna let it cook for another five to seven minutes if you want medium if you want medium rare you can do three to five minutes if you want well-done you're gonna want to do it around eight minutes now we're going to check the temperature of the state to make sure it's just right now to finish cooking your steak go ahead and put on a plate and bring it inside but a piece of floral over your steak because for the next five minutes is gonna continue to cook now that it's been sitting for five minutes we can take off the foil now let's cut into the steak and see how it turned out that color is perfect nice and juicy and that is how you grill a perfectly cooked steak thank you for watching quality eat don't forget to subscribe and like and we'll see you next time

title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: How to Grill a Perfect Steak
content: hi welcome to steak 101 the basic stick there's nothing more satisfying than cooking and serving the perfect steak so today we're gonna show you some basic techniques for oiling seasoning rusting and slicing your stick the first thing we want to do is prepare the grill we've already preheated the grill on high and we want to clean the grill real good with a grill brush to make sure that the grapes are nice and clean so that nothing will stick you can also put a little bit of oil on the grill grates themselves to prevent further sticking now it's time to prepare the sticks we've already thawed the steaks and removed the vacuum-sealed packaging the next thing we want to do is take a clean paper towel and blot any excess juice off of both sides of the steaks next we're gonna oil the sticks both sides we got here some olive oil and a brush but if you prefer you can use a can of spray olive oil that works just fine now we season the sticks we have here some sea salt and black pepper which works really good we'll do both sides but we can also use a full-featured seasoning blend such as our Omaha Steaks all natural seasoning that not only contains sea salt black pepper but other things such as onion garlic and herbs that'll really enhance the flavor of your steaks ok the steaks are ready to go on the grill now but go ahead and place them on our clean grill and we're gonna cook them to our desired doneness okay now that our steaks have reached the perfect doneness and we got some really nice searing we're gonna go ahead and take the steaks off the grill and place them on a clean platter or a clean cutting board the next step is to let the steaks rest we want to let them rest at least 5 minutes this is really important because this allows the juices to redistribute evenly throughout the steak so we have an even doneness from one end to the other ok our steaks are finished resting now we they're ready to be served we can either plate them like they are or we could slice into them for a real upscale restaurant presentation to slice them all we want to do is cut at an angle thinly and we're just gonna shingle them out and then this will allow us to fan them out on the plate and give you that real nice five-star presentation oh don't these steaks look good so that's all there is to it now you know how to prepare the steaks for the grill rest the steaks and slice it into him so now it's just a matter of getting some steaks inviting some friends over and having a barbecue

title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: How to Grill Steak - Grilling 101
content: everybody my name is Matt bronzy I'm the executive chef here at El Gaucho in Seattle and welcome to grilling 101 now there's a lot of theories out there about what to do and what not to do when you're grilling a steak today we're gonna throw a lot of those in the garbage and everything you need to know about grilling the perfect steak starts right now so the first segment we're going to talk about is heat regulation seems to be the most common cause of charred steaks and overcook steaks whether you're using a gas grill or a charcoal grill it's all the same so let's say for instance you're using a gas grill what were you gonna want to do is if there's three knobs down on the bottom I want to take the knob on the far left and I want you to crank that up all the way because that's where you're gonna do your searing in the middle knob I want you to put that on medium heat because that's where you're going to kind of cook the steak without charring it and on the far right now you're gonna turn it basically almost on low that's where you're gonna kind of bake the steak another important part to grilling is making sure you have a clean and seasoned grill what we do just want to make sure that you get all the carbon off take a dip brush a good scrape and also what you're gonna want to do next is gonna want to take in oil rag basically a rag that you don't want to keep something that's just strictly for the grill because it will get dirty so this rag has just a little bit of oil we're just gonna grease up the grill nice and good there we go now the grill is completely seasoned next what we're gonna want to do is seasoning the steaks what we have here is a filet Certified Angus beef from Neyman ranch filet what we're gonna do is just make sure that the Flay is nice and coated with steak seasoning this is our El Gaucho steak seasoning you could buy this at Metropolitan market amazon.com or here at the restaurant what you want to do is put down the presentation side first and again I'm starting on the left side because I want to get that sear because my heat is higher on the left side so there's a theory out there that you're you know when you're putting the grill or a steak on the grill or a flattop of whatever that you're actually searing in the juices and that's not necessarily true they're actually caramelizing at the top and you're searing basically kind of on the flavor of instead of sealing in the juices of mistake depending on the heating your grill you're gonna want to wait about two to three minutes per side like I said it all just depends on your Heat and how high your heat is but if you're not if you're unsure you just go ahead and take a peek it looks like we're about there you just want to get a good carmelization on that stick is that carmelization is flavor so there's a theory out there that you're only supposed to turn a steak once or limit the amount of times return the steak that theory is not necessarily true because you can flip it as many times as you want we've done lots of tests and the results are the basically the same what I'm gonna do here now that I get a good char on the other side as you can see so I'm facing the steaks facing this way I'm gonna go ahead and turn it to two o'clock it's before we were at 10 o'clock now I'm going to turn out to 2 that's why I'm gonna get my diamond marks on that so it's been about a couple minutes we're gonna flip this over see we got some really nice grill marks there and what we're gonna want to do is once we get our good sear on it we're gonna kind of bring that into the middle to the lower heat so if you enjoy a charged steak and a great way to do that is you can either use lamb fat what we use here at the restaurant or you can use bacon or butter or even a foil will be fine we're gonna do we're gonna put the steak in the hottest part so this would be on your left side of your grill you need to take some of this fat and it's gonna let it let it seep into the the flames and eventually flame up so what this does the fat drips down into the grill and it creates the the flame to shoot up and then it'll char perfectly charger steak so usually if you'd like a really good charge steak I'd leave it there for probably about two minutes three minutes let it char up really good the only way and the best way to make sure that your steak is where you want it to be is with the thermometer unless you cook a lot of steaks sometimes you just get the feel for it and sometimes you're able to touch it and kind of know where it's at but I think the thermometer is your best insurance policy you need to make sure that you don't over cook your steak once again my name is Matt bronzy I'm the executive chef here at El Gaucho in Seattle I hope you learned a lot from this grilling lesson and we hope to see you at the restaurant

content: hey this is Tristan at hip cooks in West Los Angeles and today we're going to talk about steak cooking a steak there are so many cuts to the cow and it's sometimes difficult to choose what to cook I tend to like t-bone steak and sirloin they have a nice amount of fat in them they have a lot of flavor and the best cut is going to be with the bone-in so if you can't get the bone in there keep it in it adds the flavor and it's something to gnaw on when you're done yummy YUM so here I have a t-bone steak and it gets its name cuz it kind of has a t in it can see it's a seasoned this steak I'm just gonna use basic salt and pepper and a little bit of garlic for garlic just take a clove and cut some chunks of the garlic I think one will be enough for this size couple chunks and I will cut little slits into the steak around the bone maybe one or two in the middle where you see some of the marbling and push in some of these little bits to flavor the meat my grandpa taught me this one adds nice flavor you can see that this steak is about about an inch thick which is fine the thickness of your meat will depend on how long you cook it so we are going to be cooking this for about five minutes aside in a high Brailler if you have a thicker steak you will want to cook it for six to seven minutes per side okay so a little salt just a little pinch will do on each side and a little bit of pepper pepper to really depending on how much you want okay so we did the first side now let's go to the second side again just cut some holes in the steak along the bone and maybe one in the middle of the marbling and find those little pockets and put in some garlic okay and a little more salt pepper so that steaks ready to go this is a quick preparation the pan the broiling pan is in the oven I've set the broiler to high and I've set the broiling pan on the middle rack so it's been preheated so when I throw this on I should get a good sizzle follow me over to the oven that's the sound we want okay so about four minutes per side so in four minutes I'll flip it over okay the steak is ready to take out as Evan all right so what I did I left the steak in there for four minutes on one side and after four minutes I flipped it check the temperature it's running at 120 just where I want it because I want a medium-rare steak and I'll cover it for about five minutes and while it's covered the temperature will rise to probably 125 which is the perfect temperature so in total this is about six minutes of cooking and again it really depends on the thickness of your steak so don't just read the cookbook and say okay four minutes the side after you flip it test the temperature to make sure that it doesn't get overcooked one last thing with steak you can certainly do this in a skillet the reason I didn't is because I don't like my house smelling like steak nor do I want splattery fat all over my oven so this is kind of a cleaner way to do it but either way the cooking process is the same for approximately four minutes aside and flip let it sit for five minutes and it's ready to serve enjoy your steak thanks for watching if there any other dishes you'd like to see me prepare please send us an email at request at Mahalo calm and in the meantime check out our other videos

content: what are you - this your boy Sonny this is the first episode of sunny side-up um and today when we do a state so today we're going to be doing state guys and the specific sake we have is called flat iron now flat iron comes from the cow's abdomen section and so it has a really good nice beefy flavor and it's not very fatty and the way you want to cook this steak is you want to cook it medium wire to medium no more than the medium because if you do it'll get tough but if you cook it like that this steak I'm telling you guys I preferred over filet mignon and I know it sounds crazy but it's that good okay guys so now we're going to actually season our meat and this is coarse salt it has a little more texture than regular salt and don't be shy with the seasonings this is a thick thick cut of beef um and so do not do not be liberal with your salt and pepper on it um so yeah just try to get it everywhere everywhere you can and now we're just going to flip it over just like that and actually press the salt in a little bit because you want it to stay on there get into the meat and it'll create a nice crust when we when we take it out to grill it you just want to turn our beef like that and you see these little things right here you can remove that um you don't have to it doesn't really make that much of a difference but if you want you can remove it this out it's very small amount but if there's large amounts of this silver skin you just want to take that off and so we're just going to salt both sides and now we're just going to put some pepperoni you can use black pepper you can use pink pepper and actually picking peppers not really peppers this is the type of berries but like I said do not be liberal with your pepper for salt and you see I'm not washing my hands after I touch this Romney you guys want to wash your hands I'm going to watch everything that I've touched but just be careful not to cross contaminate anything with the beef or anything else in the kitchen because you can get sick like that and I'm in pepper on the other side press it in and now we're ready to grill our meat just ok so now the next step is actually grilling our steak and what you're what you're going to need for this is you're going to need a really hot grill like we have here and this extra really nice grill and it's been preheating ours is about at 600 degrees so that's probably the temperature you want around there you want to go to higher and you could go a little lower or not too much and so what we're going to do now is we have our steak here and I'm going to use a fork to put it on and then the thongs to take it off because I want to use two different things so I don't cross-contaminate so I'm just gonna stick it in the beef and we want to hear a sizzle as we put it down and that's perfect you hear that sizzle I think you can hear it all the way over there can't you and so what we're going to do now is we're just going to cover this puppy up we'll turn the fire down here and we're going to let that grill without opening it for about nine minutes per side it's a big piece of meat and we wanted to kick it to to a medium and remember after we're done grilling this we're going to let it sit for at least 10 minutes so it's going to continue to cook so that the juices seatback in and we end up with a juicy steak okay guys it's been about nine minutes on one side so now we're ready to flip our steak we're going to take our fork and now put it down on the other side that's perfect you see we got those nice grill marks on each side now we're going to close this and let it go for another nine minutes exactly how it was you can check on it maybe once or twice but try not to keep this open keep it closed so uh so it stays nice and hot in there hey guys so it hasn't been exactly nine minutes but because of the texture of the state I can pretty much tell you that it's done it's been about five to six minutes on the second time so so it's all about um it's all about just really seeing really seeing what your stake is doing what your food is doing you know touching I'm touching and it's pretty firm so another ten minutes of letting it cook by itself and the steak should be perfectly medium guys our steak has been resting for ten minutes all the juices has seeped back into the meat so now when we cut it it won't come running out now we're ready to cut okay guys so before we cut the steak really important to remember this steak if you don't cut it against the grain which means that you're cutting it against the the way the meat grain runs along the meat your it's going to be more tough because of the the fibers in there so the grain on this state runs this way so we're going to do is we're going to start here and we're going to cut it this way diagonally the whole steak so let's get cutting and then in the middle might be a little more medium-rare but that's how you want to eat these steaks because if not if you cook it any more in the medium it's going to be a tough fibrous steak so you can see we cut our meat and look at that it's perfectly medium perfectly medium it's pink all the way through and that's exactly what we want so now the moment of truth guys you know I gotta try this I've been salivating the whole time and now it's the verdict hmm Wow boys and girls this is liquid gold oh wait so guys that are sunny-side up I'm sunny god bless the United State

content: hi folks Keith Roberts here coming to you from s Wallace Edwards and Sons in a storage Surrey Virginia and today I got a great grilling recipe for you it's a classic burger topped with our famous bacon steak now our ingredient list is really quite simple on this one I have two 8-ounce ground chuck patties some fresh sliced heirloom tomatoes Vidalia onion and we're going to finish the burger off with some of our quarter inch thick sliced bacon steak all right so since our burgers are on the large size a full eight ounce ground chuck patty I'm going to go ahead and get those on the grill first now one of the reasons I prefer using ground chuck over a basic ground beef just think it has a little bit better flavor profile and you can get a little bit more fat in it and that really does bring flavor to your burgers most people tend to do a lot of flipping in all honesty you want to leave them on each side and really only flip them once during the entire cooking process that means we're probably going to let these burgers cook for a minimum of three to four minutes to each side that should give us about a medium burger by the time all is said and done now we have the burgers working next I'm going to go ahead and put the Vidalia onion on the Vidalia is a little bit sweeter running as you can see I did some pretty thick slices and I'm going to go ahead and put those on the grill off to the side a little bit so they're not quite over direct heat now something else about using a thicker sliced onion it'll help that hold together throughout the whole cooking process and finally I'm going to go ahead and put the bacon steak on the grill now most people don't think about grilling bacon but since our bacon steak is sliced a full quarter inch thick it will hold up to a mighty hot grill now these burgers have been on for about three to four minutes we should have a good char going on the other side so I'm going to go ahead and give them a flip and these are looking perfect and here's what you can really see what i mean about only wanting to flip burgers once during the cooking process we got that nice char which means we've already started ceiling in some of those great flavors and juices and now that we have the burgers flipped I'm going to go ahead and flip the Vidalia onion it can be kind of handy if you use both the spatula and a pair of tongs on this one you really want to try and keep the whole onion in one piece as you can see we're starting to get a few grill marks vidalias and the nice thing about grilling these is that the heat brings out some of the natural sugars that you find in this sweet variety of onion now our bacon steak has been on for about two minutes so I'm going to go ahead and give that a flip you can see we're starting to get some nice browning on there the last thing you want to do is burn any bacon but you'll also see that it's holding up really well over this intense heat of the grill one thing you'll notice about our bacon steak is that it doesn't shrink a whole lot and that's because all we do here at Edwards is a true dry cure that means you're not cooking all the water out of that store-bought bacon out there the dry cure process also brings an absolutely unique flavor to your bacon ok so the burgers have been on the grill for about eight to ten minutes now remember these were pretty big burgers so just watch your time to get that temperature that you're looking for our bday lees have been on for about six they have some nice grill marks the onion has started to soften up a little bit and the bacon steak is cooked right where I want it about medium and temperature or wobbly since it's a dry cure it'll actually set up once I pull it off the heat so there you have it folks our very own version of a Vidalia onion tomato and bacon steak burger compliments of us wallis Edwards and Sons

title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: Pro Grilling Tips | How to Choose The Perfect Steak and The Best Way to Grill It!!!
content: everybody I'm Jamie provides and today I want to share with you some ideas on how to choose a steak and get it ready for grilling because sometimes the decisions you make in the store and what you do to prep the steak make as much of a difference as your techniques on the grill so let's look at a couple of steaks that I picked up at the store one of them I really like and the other I don't like so much and I'll tell you why this one over here is a good-looking steak and the reason is is primarily the marbling the thickness the bone and the integrity the marbling is the fat basically the little streaks of milky white fat running through the steak are really important for the juiciness of the steak and for the flavor here the modeling is nice and evenly distributed over here I don't see as much distribution of fat and the fat that is around is is clumped up there are large sections of fat the problem with that is that those tend to melt pretty quickly and potentially cause flare-ups they also cause some gaps in the steak see how this one for instance this is this a bit of fat here is right between two muscles basically and when that melts away there's going to be a hole and the steak is basically going to fall apart you're going to have a scraggly piece of meat over here the clumps are not so big the meat is held a little bit better together it has better integrity I think that makes for a better steak overall now another big issue is the thickness of the state both of them are roughly an inch maybe an inch and a quarter thick and that's a pretty good thickness to start with you want to go higher than that rather than lower than that a thin steak tends to over cook really quickly in the center it's hard to see or both sides of the steak and still leave the interior and you know nice and juicy and rosy red so I find that about an inch is the minimum you can go and of course the thickness should be even throughout you can see that this one was cut so that one end of the steak is actually much thinner than the other end and that's going to create some unevenness of doneness so you want to have a nice even thickness throughout so once you've got a well marbled evenly cut perfectly big bone in ribeye steak how do you get it ready for the grill well I think one of the most important things to do is to salt the steak 20 to 30 minutes before you grill it a couple really important things happen during that time number one the steak loses its very cold temperature right it comes out of the refrigerator very cold and if you were to put it right on the grill immediately it would actually take longer to cook and the longer that it cooks on the grill the greater the chance that it's going to dry out okay as you cook any piece of meat juices are pushed out of the meat and so with a steak the idea is to cook it pretty much as quickly as possible without actually burning it of course another really important thing happens during this time is that the salt begins to work on the steak you've probably heard that salt draws moisture out of a steak right and you don't want to do that for hours and hours and hours because you'll dry out the steak and that's true but if you do it for just 20 or 30 minutes actually that little bit of moisture that comes to the surface of the steak makes for a beautiful really delicious crust on the surface so if you just take a little bit of care to pick a great looking stick and season it well ahead of time you set yourself up for a great dining experience now it's just a matter of firing up the grill and letting the meat hit the heat

title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: How to Grill a Perfect Steak - T-Bone Steak Recipe
content: hey everybody welcome to the Wolfe pit tonight we're gonna do some t-bone steaks and baked potatoes on the grill dough so let's get started the grill dome is preheated to 400 degrees I have two russet potatoes that have rubbed an olive oil salt and pepper and I'm not gonna foil these if you follow me you won't have the nice crispy skin on the outside so leave it on for now close the lid and these will take just about an hour to cook now to keep the grill dome at 400 degrees I have the top vent open about 25% and the bottom vent open 25% and that'll hold it into 400 degrees as long as I wanted to while the potatoes are cooking I have two one-pound t-bone steaks and I want to bring up to room temperature you never want to cook a cold steak the heat and the cold mix together will shock the meat and make it tough and force the juices out and I'm just gonna simply season these with salt and pepper after an hour and 15 minutes our potatoes are done and you can tell this by taking your meat probe and just slide it into the thickest part of the potato and it should not have any resistance at all and now we're ready to go ahead and grill our state's I've increased the temperature up to about five hundred and fifty degrees I'm not sure if it looks like 550 degrees from that angle but it's at 550 degrees listen to that sear I'm gonna grill these for four minutes per side for a perfect medium-rare after two minutes give them a half a term for the crosshatch grill marks after another two minutes we're gonna flip our steaks and let them go for more minutes after cooking for total eight minutes our steaks are done now let's cut into the state and see how we did I've got to say that is a perfectly cook state look at how moist and juicy I topped the potato with a little bit of butter and Colby jack cheese and it was outstanding thank you guys very much for watching I hope you give this a try and we'll see you next time

there for a moment or two you can see that down near the grilling surface we have temperatures of in the 90s and then as I pull that probe through the state you'll see that it gets lower and lower internal temperature of that state and the different numbers of called gradient this steak is cooking from the bottom up there's a hot grill surface and kind of a cool top and it's cooking from the title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: Charcoal grilling - How to grill a porterhouse steak
content: hi I'm Eli Iglesias executive chef Morton steakhouse and today I'm going to show you how to grill the perfect porterhouse steak porterhouse is the best of both worlds you have your filet and your sirloin you want to pick a steak that's at least an inch to an inch and a half and thickness one that has a nice red color and abundant marbling the marbling or all the little fat specks that you can see which is going to give the steak its buttery flavor and tenderness you can season the steak with seasoning salt or just salt and pepper before you even throw the steak on the grill you want to make sure your coals are at least on for 45 minutes and there are a nice bright white color once you put the steak on the grill always cover it once you've covered the grill keep it covered resist the urge to open it up and peek inside make sure you leave the steak at least 5 minutes so they can get a nice crust on the one side that's going to seal all the juices and flavor in the steak after about five minutes that steak should be ready to flip remember always use a pair of tongs when flipping a steak don't use a fork all you're gonna do is poke holes in it and let all those juices out and remember keep it covered in about another four minutes this steak should be a perfect medium-rare the best way to tell if the steak is ready is with a very simple hand trick a medium-rare steak if you just like the base of your thumb soft and spongy with some give while a medium steak should feel more like the center of your palm less spongy and a little bit more firm a medium-rare steak should have a hot red center and there you have it the perfectly grilled porterhouse steak enjoy

title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: How to cook the perfect Steak
content: [Music] so how to cook the perfect steak it's a question that I get asked all the time and I'm going to show you my way how I think the perfect steak should be and it starts with getting the right cut now I'm using the ribeye or as we call it here in Australia in New Zealand the Scotch fill it and it's from that rib area so it's flavorful and tender and it slightly works being that rib area in the rib cage and this marbling makes it perfect for cooking the best steak because it can take a lot of heat and it can take it nice and fast which is exactly how we want to cook our steak so first of all what we're going to do is just oil our steak I don't Aurel the pan I always put the oil onto the steak and I just rub it into the steak like that and then I seasoned really really well with lots of cracked pepper little or as much pepper as you want but I use nice lots of salt because that's how you going to get that nice crust on the outside and just Pat it down lightly and then turn it over and all those bits of salt and pepper that are on the plate you just want to soak them up and then do exactly the same to this side here so that's all the prep that we have to do with our steak we're now ready to cook it so the next couple of steps to the perfect steak one is to have your pan smoking hot I've got nothing in here and you can see the pan just smoking away and that's how you want it because soon as you put the steak in a lot of that heat in the pan is gone it just like that in a blink it's gone the second thing is your steak must be at room temperature so before you do the last part make sure you have your steak out about twenty to thirty minutes before you actually start seasoning it and cooking it because it's going to cook evenly so we're going to get our steak and put it straight down in the pan and that's the sound you want to hear that nice sizzling sound now I haven't oiled the pan because I've got oil on the steak but I will be popping a little bit of oil in there in a short time when we flavor it up with some butter as well but a good way to how you want your steak cooked is right in the palm of your hand now if you take your hand like that right there is rare right there is medium rare right there is medium and right there is well-done so depending on how you like your steak I like mine medium rare but depending on how you like yours that's how you cook it just by touching it and feeling it you'll get the same feeling in the palm of your hand it's been about a minute so we're going to turn our steak over and you can see there those beautiful marks that say exactly how I want my steak now I turn it every minute so it cooks evenly on both sides now I want to start rendering some of that fat that's down the side so all we have to do is pick up the steak put it down straight on the pan like that and we just want to caramelize and render that fat down now I'm going to add a little bit more olive oil to the pan and I'm also going to add in a knob of butter as well and then on top of the butter I've got some fresh thyme just throw it in there just push this leg over get that time get all the fragrance is released and then just get the pan and start tossing all that butter and juice straight over the top of the steak and all those flavors will infuse on top of the steak and do the same on this side with the steak as well so I'm now going to take it out of the pan and leave it to rest now that to me is how you cook the perfect steak but what I like to do is just take it up a notch and this is optional if you wanted to stop there you've got the most amazing steak after you've let it rest for about four to five minutes but what I like to do now is paint one side with Dijon mustard just all over the top and then what I'm going to do I've got some fresh chopped up chives and I'm just going to place our steak the mustard side down and just press into those chives and when we lift up we will have all those chives stuck to the steak and it is just glorious and all we have to do is just cut our steaks and oh just smells so good [Music] so slice it up just like that and look how beautiful and medium-rare and all that pink in there just looks glorious and I'm just going to sprinkle over just some baby parsley just over the top just to finish it off and that is how I make my perfect steak I'm telling you that meat is so flavorful and tender that my knife just runs straight through it it is like cutting butter it is truly amazing packed full of flavor and those tribes and that mustard is truly incredible now you know how to make the perfect steak I suggest you go out and make it [Music] you [Music]

title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: How to Grill Buffalo Steaks : Recipes for Steaks
content: hey everybody I'm chef Eddie G from coast-to-coast cuisine and today we're gonna grill a buffalo steak one of my favorites the first thing you'll notice about a buffalo steak is how lean it is there's almost no fat so although we are grilling it today a good way to cook this is to pan sear it as well very light on the spices too you don't want to put a lot to it there's not a lot of gay meanness although you do hear that Buffalo is a little gamey this Buffalo is not gamey at all so you're gonna love this cut of meat and the spices I'll be using today is a little bit of salt and then I have this rub I call it an Eddie G rub and then I also have a little bit of white pepper with some garlic and a little bit of onion powder in there so delicious nice and simple you don't need a lot on there just a little so what we're gonna do is we're gonna take the Buffalo I've added just a little bit of oil on there and just a little bit of pepper just a little bit of salt and just a little bit of that Eddie G rub that I've got going on so what we'll do is we'll take that piece of meat and face down right on there like that and then just a little more spices right on this end that chef Eddie G spice delicious and then what we'll do is we'll give it a nice little grill marks on there and it'll come out perfect so what I like to do is I like to put grill marks on the meat so you do a little 3/4 turn just like that and when that does is it gives you the nice grill marks on there and we're doing about a minute on each a minute on each for about medium-rare on a steak this size you want to take it out before you start cooking it so that it comes down to room temperature so if you do like it rare or medium rare the inside isn't cold if we had smell-o-vision mmm smells fantastic you don't want to play with it too much just put the meat on there let it work let it cook and then what you could do is flip it right over and you get those beautiful grill marks on there things I like to do too is just add a little bit of high-quality virgin olive oil on there that around look at how that shine okay and you see we've created these grill marks here we're gonna give it another 3/4 of a turn and now the whole outside of the meat should be pretty much cooked as you see so only do the grill marks look beautiful but it's also a way for the chef to time how well the meat is done if you want a rare piece of meat this size it would be about four minutes so it's one minute then a 3/4 turn for another minute then flip it over for the third minute and then another 3/4 turn for the fourth minute like you just saw me do so this one will be about I'd say medium-rare somewhere right around there so take a look what we've done we've put the grill marks right on that piece of meat look at how beautiful so what we're gonna do is put it right on the plate there a little parsley and I love just a little confetti right around the corner there look at how that makes the color pop off of this thing beautiful isn't it enjoy the nice thing about Buffalo too is it's so lean and so healthy most of it is grass-fed they never use steroids or any kind of preservatives or additives to the meat itself so it's so healthy for you it's actually more healthy than a lean piece of meat and a special thanks to Zee carpentry located in Islandia Long Island for letting us use their custom designed kitchen so this is how you grill a buffalo steak I'm chef Eddie G from coast to coast cuisine and cooking is my passion stay hungry my friends

title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: How to Grill a Steak Cooked Medium Rare | Tips to Grilling a Medium Rare Steak #steak #mediumrare
content: everyone I'm Lindsay and today I'm going to show you how to grill the perfect steak with a medium-rare Center now there's a few things you got to remember before you go ahead and start cooking first take the steak out of the refrigerator 20 minutes before you want to start grilling we want the steak at room temperature second you want to rub some oil so on pepper on mistake so that it has a nice rub on it for the grill and lastly and most importantly you want the grill to be as hot as possible so that we can sear the outside of the steak now the steak we're cooking with today is about an inch and a half to an inch and a quarter thick so the times we leave the steak on will be for this side steak don't worry if your steak is thicker or thinner I made a nice chart for you so it's so simple to adjust the times on how long you want to get a nice medium-rare steak so the first side of the steak is going to take 5 minutes to grill like weber says looking ant cooking we need to keep the lid closed so that the heat does not escape from the grill now there's an easy way to tell what the temperature of the inside of your steak is without cutting it open or using a thermometer if you put your index finger and your thumb together and touch right here that's what a rare steak will feel like if you put your thumb and your middle finger together like this tap right here that's what a medium steak will feel like if you put your ring finger and your thumb together and tap right here that's what a well steak will feel like the second side of the steak is going to take 5 minutes to grill when the timer goes off you want to take the steak off of the grill and go ahead and loosely cover it on a plate under tinfoil we want to let the steak repose for five to seven minutes under the tinfoil once the steak is reposed we're ready to go ahead and cut it open thank you all so much for watching I hope you enjoy your steak please remember to Like subscribe comment and stay tuned for more DIY videos

content: hey guys what's up it's Steve so I've had a lot of requests from not only family and friends but also so from some of you guys out there to show you how I like to cook steaks inside the kitchen so obviously if you follow my channel you know that I do pretty much 99% of my cooking outside on the grill but a lot of people you know either are in a situation where they don't have a grill or maybe they just don't like to grill whatever it is and they just prefer to cook inside the kitchen so the great thing is that you can cook an amazing steak inside of the kitchen obviously they do that at restaurants all the time really high-end steak houses and things like that what I'm gonna be showing you how to do is my preferred method it's a reverse sear that I've showed you guys how to do outside on some of my grills but we're gonna do this with the oven and then a cast-iron skillet I bought some massively thick New York strips that we're gonna cook up so let's go ahead and get started okay so when you're gonna be doing a reverse sear one of the first things you want to do is make sure you get some super thick steak since we're gonna be cooking low and slow in the oven first and just slowly bringing up that temperature and then searing on the finisher just works so much better when you have a nice thick steak I ran across these beast New York strips these guys are about an inch and a half thick they're just enormous they're on sale for $5.99 a pound so I jumped on that and all you want to do is just take some kosher salt and we want to salt both sides fairly liberally all right and flip them over and for those of you that may be new to this process what this is doing is that the the meat is going to basically draw the salt into the center of the meat and so it's gonna provide some extra flavor and it's gonna help tenderize it and so what we're gonna do is after you've got both sides nice and salted these are gonna sit out at room temperature for anywhere between 45 minutes and 1 hour okay so I let these strips set out for one hour in room temp so at this point it's time to put these in the oven so we're gonna go ahead and give a nice little sprinkle of crushed black pepper on both sides okay so now what I've done you want to take a wire rack so you can get these elevated off your pan so you just have some nice air flow going underneath there that's just gonna help with a nice even cook and then the single most important part of this reverse sear method is using a high accuracy food thermometer so we're going to be using the thermo work chef alarm since these steaks are basically almost identical in size I'm just gonna take my food probe here and just slide it straight into the middle of that guy right there okay so again our oven is preheated to 250 degrees we're gonna go and get our steaks in and then we're gonna go ahead and get our probe connected here to our chef's alarm all right and so you can see here I've got the high alarm set to 115 because that's when I want to pull these and we'll pull them out and get our cast iron screaming hot for that finishing sear so we'll pick up pick back up in just a bit okay guys so it has been right at 45 minutes and the chef's alarm is reading out at 115 degrees so we're gonna go ahead and pull these bad boys and let those sit for a second and then we're gonna get our cast iron skillet cranked up to a just searing hot tub okay guys we have our cast iron skillet just raging hot and I'm going to be using about a quarter cup of grapeseed oil and then we're going to go ahead and get these guys in here it's like that alright so let me turn this fan off this for a second so you can hear me it's about every 30 seconds I'm gonna give these a flip and then I'm gonna be monitoring these very closely with my fountain pen and so each flip I'll just come in here and give it a quick little read alright I just flip them again now we're gonna add some butter these are just about done and just continue to flip all right these are about 1:30 and so I'm gonna go ahead and pull these all right then what I like to do right here on the finish is just put a little pat of content: greetings longtime friends and new viewers my name is Dan Delaney and every day during 2011 I'm picking a new food that's unusual and exploring it for you folks out there in honor of this warm weather that we're starting to experience as well as the impending Memorial Day I thought we'd dedicate a whole week of content to grilling and grilling related episodes so this is WTF grilling week episode 1 we've got a bunch of great sponsors lined up for the different episodes during grilling week and we're starting off with stagecoach sauces which you can check out online at stagecoach sauces dot-com stagecoach produces a number of different types of sauces that are all great for barbecuing and grilling ok we're going to take a look at their steak sauce which like all of their sauces is free of high fructose corn syrup free of preservatives free of additives free of other not healthy ingredients it's all really raw ingredients that are good for you and are natural they also make a great ruby red garlic sauce which is awesome for marinating chicken and grilling chicken with but today we're going to focus on the steak we're gonna use their sick sauce along with our dinner check them out online at stagecoach sauces calm all right I figured that it was best to start a grilling week with grilling 101 so before we get into the complicated recipes we're going to take today's episode and really talk about the history of grilling and some tips and tricks to make your grilling experience really easy and fun grilling is probably the oldest and I think the manliest way to cook meat it's meat on top of fire there's no messing with that as far as its aged people believe that grilling started about 500,000 years ago it's a long time grilling didn't really do much evolving until the 1950s prior to the 1950s young is always a communal act he would grill in public parks or way back in the day they would grow on a bonfire however everything changed in the 1950s in the 1950s a guy named George Stevens inherited a company called Weber brother metals and I'll go now that company was primarily known for making booties which are these devices that go out into the water to help guide chips home and into port he took one of the buoys cut it in half through a grill inside and drilled some holes and created the first weber grill and weber grills took off the buoy business sunk and basically everybody bought these grills for their home use that was the first time that grilling went from a communal act that only happened in public places to a backyard activity fun fact the phrase come to a backyard barbecue is actually often wrong because the art of barbecuing is very different than the art of grilling grilling you're cooking with radiant heat and it's direct heat the cooking things also very quickly barbecue is all about low and slow it's about indirect and it's all about smoke and today there are generally two camps of grills for your home some people go with a gas grill which uses a gas source like propane the propane heats up a bunch of permanent briquettes that are stored inside of your grill great they hold all of the warmth and transfer that warmth to your meat the other type of grill is a charcoal grill in a charcoal grill the actual lumps of charcoal hold all the heat are on fire and they transfer the heat directly to the meat regardless of the type of grill that you have I have a few tips for you that will make your grilling experience a lot better and your food tastier tip number one is create heat zones don't put Arklow all through the bottom of your grill as it's just going to create a blanket of heat and it's not going to give you any room for play instead put all of your heat source on one side of the grill whether that means turning on one side of the burners or putting your charcoal around one side keep the other side open now you'll be able to move your steak or your burger from the hot side to the cooler side and have more control over the cooking temperature and time point two is keep it clean I recommend using natural lump charcoal and using a charcoal chimney as opposed to using something like lighter fluid for number three we have three essential tools for grilling number one is aluminum foil I prefer the heavy duty varietal it'll allow you to tent your meat you can also crumple up your aluminum foil to help clean off your grill grate before you put the meat down number two would be a spatula from metal spatula the same way that you would flip fish with is a great option for the grill and number three is a tongue it is the most versatile tool in your kitchen I recommend getting metal tongues so they don't melt while you're moving things around over the hot Heat number four is know the temperature of your food food dries out very quickly on a grill so it's helpful to have a thermometer on hand you know exactly what the temperature is and be prepared to move things off the grill about five to ten degrees before they hit the temperature point that you want them at because they will continue to cook another rule of thumb is actually the rule of thumb you can simulate the doneness of meat and then compare and contrast by moving your fingers around on your hand if you feel this pushy part of your thumb right now it is the same texture that a rare piece of steak will be if you pinch your first two together you have medium rare medium medium-well and well-done so as I move my fingers together it's tougher and tougher just like the steak will become the more you cook it alright so today we are going to go through some of the basics setting up a charcoal grill and growing a steak couldn't be simpler first put some tightly crumpled newspaper in the bottom of your charcoal chimney add a few pieces of lump charcoal on top light up the newspaper and allow it to heat up your charcoal depending on the size of the grill and the amount of food that you're cooking I recommend putting some charcoal in the beginning letting that heat up and then slowly adding more I find that if you put all the charcoal in your chimney at once and then heat it up it doesn't heat up thoroughly and it actually goes out before it really eats up while the charcoal in your chimney is heating up you're going to pour more charcoal into your grill remember keep it on one side only once the charcoal and your chimney is ashy and white pour that charcoal carefully over your grill and over the other charcoal cover up your grill and let eat up when the majority of your charcoal has caught fire and is a bit white you're ready to grill lay down a steak seasoned with salt and pepper season early and let it kind of work its way into the meat before you throw it on the grill I'm using a strip steak bone out it's about an inch and a half thick another quick tip if you keep your meat in the refrigerator you want to let it come to room temp trip about 20 minutes before you put it on the grill all you're going to do is make the cook time and temperature uneven and the result will be a charred piece of meat on the outside that is basically Raw on the inside you don't want that I'm also going to cook up some asparagus just toss it in a little bit of vegetable oil because it's a high heat oil with salt and pepper and put that on the grill as well cook the steak for about four minutes on each side remember to use the rule of thumb to determine how well your meat is cooked and when it's done you're going to take it off and tent it in some aluminum foil for about five minutes before you eat so the juices get to reabsorb and it gets to rest so that's my grilling 101 episode and that's how to grill a steak remember to check out stagecoach sausage calm and tune in all throughout this week to hear a bunch of different episodes about all different wild ways to grill see tomorrow on what C's food

title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: How to Grill the Perfect Stove Top Steak - Beginner Cooking Tips - Circulon
content: stove top grilling is a great way to develop rich seared flavor on the outside of a steak while cooking it to perfection on the inside before cooking rest your steak at room temperature for 30 minutes Pat the steak dry with a paper towel drying the meat allows it to brown and develop a flavorful crusty exterior rub the steak with a light coating of olive oil just before cooking season the meat evenly with salt and pepper on both sides use a grill pan that is large enough to comfortably fit your steaks if they are crowded they'll steam instead of grill heat the pan over medium-high heat add the steak and let it cook undisturbed without moving it around by letting the meat grill to a deep caramelized brown crust you ensure full and complex flavors now it's time to flip your steak over cooking the steak rare will take about 3 minutes per side medium-rare about 4 minutes per side check for doneness by using an instant-read thermometer or by touch to gauge how cooked the steak is by touch press the steak with a pair of tongs or the back of a spoon the amount the meat gives indicates how done it is the softer the meat the rarer it is the firmer the meat the more cooked it is after cooking let the steak rest for a few minutes to allow the juices to redistribute the meat will continue to cook another few degrees during this resting time so allow for this when deciding to remove the steak from the pan

paper towel drying the meat allows it to
brown and develop a flavorful crusty
exterior
rub the steak with a light coating of
olive oil just before cooking season the
meat evenly with salt and pepper on both
sides
use a grill pan that is large enough to
comfortably fit your steaks if they are
crowded they'll steam instead of grill
heat the pan over medium-high heat add
the steak and let it cook undisturbed
without moving it around by letting the
meat grill to a deep caramelized brown
crust you ensure full and complex
flavors now it's time to flip your steak
over cooking the steak rare will take
about 3 minutes per side medium-rare
about 4 minutes per side check for
doneness by using an instant-read
thermometer or by touch to gauge how
cooked the steak is by touch press the
steak with a pair of tongs or the back
of a spoon the amount the meat gives
indicates how done it is the softer the
meat the rarer it is the firmer the meat
the more cooked it is after cooking let
the steak rest for a few minutes to
allow the juices to redistribute the
meat will continue to cook another few
degrees during this resting time so
allow for this when deciding to remove
the steak from the pan

title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: How to Cook Steak on the Stove - Steak Recipe Easy
content: how to cook steak on the stove knowing how to cook steak on the stove comes in very handy because there are times when you can't use a grill using a wood or charcoal grill for cooking steak improves the flavor because of the smoke however it is still possible to make a pretty decent tasting steak using your frying pan when cooking steak on your stove you will get the best results if it is a quality piece of meat like a tenderloin steak tenderloin which is also known as filet mignon is one of the best cuts for stovetop cooking it is lean tender and juicy you will bring out the best flavor of the tenderloin steak if you don't cook it beyond medium-rare here are the steps 1 2 start cooking your steak take it out of the refrigerator for at least 20 minutes before so that it can warm up to room temperature 2 take some paper towels and Pat the tenderloin dry to absorb any extra moisture if you're using a dry rub massage it into the meat however because tenderloin is a piece of quality meat even salt and pepper should be enough 3 after rubbing on salt and pepper or the dry rub rub a bit of oil on both sides of the steak for heat a skillet over the stove a heavy one will be able to retain and distribute heat properly you will know that it's hot enough when a few drops of water sizzle and dance before evaporating five drop a tablespoon of oil into the hot skillet and move it around so that the cooking surface is lightly coated 6 when the oil starts to smoke place the tenderloin stake in the middle of the pan sear the steak for two to three minutes to seal in the juices and the flavor 7 using a Tong not a fork or knife flip the steak and sear the other side you don't want to poke any holes in the meat because doing so will cause the juices to run out making the meat less juicy don't skip the searing searing creates delicious crust outside of the steak 8 lower the heat to medium and continue cooking the steak for 10 more minutes flipping every now and then remember that you don't want to pierce the steak 9 take the steak out of the skillet when you think that it would be done in about two more minutes this is because the steak will continue to cook after you take it out of the skillet so timing it this way will ensure that it is done just enough 10 place the steak on a plate and cover loosely with aluminum foil let it rest for about 15 minutes to allow the juices to be reabsorbed into the meat and to develop the flavor 11 take the skillet that you use to cook the steak and deglaze it by putting in a tablespoon of butter and two tablespoons of water place it over medium heat and use a spatula to remove any charged juices so that they mix with the water and butter let it simmer for a few more minutes to reduce it a little this reduced liquid will then be drizzled over the tenderloins to make the outsides a bit moister you can also learn how to cook steak on a stove using lesser quality meats such as chuck steak or other cuts however because meats that are graded below select or tougher and drier they tend to be more suited for white cooking methods such as stewing

here i've got some round sticks or we actually cut these steaks from a round roast all right now round roast as you know or the cut around from the beef is tough real tough right and the only way to tenderize it is um is to stew it right which is often done or marinate the hell out of it and that's what we're gonna do here now we'll trim this um fat off of these steaks right here because the fats not gonna do anything in this case this is a hard fat we don't need it we're gonna get rid of it now like i said round steaks are tough so it'll require a good 24-hour marinade for this steak right now if you use like a rib steak or a cubed steak from round yeah you won't have to marinate it so long but uh in this case we're going to marinate it to get it nice and tender so what i'm doing here is cutting up some fries right now if you're here because you're looking for steak fries made from taters you've come to the wrong place this is real steak fries we're using steak there's not a potato within 50 miles here of the pit now we've got them cut up in basic fry size you can make them bigger or smaller and we'll throw them in this two and a half gallon plastic bag you know use a marinade and dish or whatever you have and now we'll make the marinade and it's real easy and it'll be real tangy and a perfect snack food for a nice cold beer we're starting out with one-third cup of worcestershire sauce all right this is going to be nice and tangy and uh here we're gonna add about a third a cup of soy sauce this would bring a nice saltiness to this beer snack food right now if you've never had a steak fry before a real steak fry you definitely gotta check this out and you better make a ton of them for that game you got going on right now here we've got some balsamic vinegar and we're at about a third a cup of balsamic vinegar and you need the balsamic right it's a mellower taste not so vinegar taste so you don't want to use regular table vinegar right use a good balsamic now for this recipe you're gonna need some minced garlic and we've got about a teaspoon used more or less and here we've got a teaspoon of onion powder right now because this is beer snack and food we're gonna season it a little bit more right so we've got our spg at least seasoned a little bit of salt and pepper or whatever you got your favorite seasoning salt will do all right and even though we got the soy sauce in there and uh here we're also adding some fresh ground black peppercorn pepper is always good for that steak all right [Music] now what i'm gonna do is um of course mix it up math make a bunch of these all right now like i said in the miracle of time 24 hours has gone by actually um we did this a day before and we're ready to fry them so we'll take these uh steak fries here throw them in the egg wash then right in to the bag of flour and mix just like that you get it right or you've done this before like i said this recipe is going to be real easy to do i'm telling you martha wherever you are we're going to be eating good tonight now you shake up the bag with your uh slices of steak and coat it really well [Music] now it happens to be only about 28 degrees fahrenheit out here so everything is nice and cold if you're doing in this in the summer or warm weather you may want to um you may want to take these coated steak fries and keep them refrigerated title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: How to grill a $150 Tomahawk Steak
content: hey pitmasters today we're gonna be grilling a hundred and fifty dollar steak and we're gonna love every minute of it [Music] look at this beautiful cut of beef it's absolutely gorgeous 2.7 kilograms will be a Gallagher louia Gallagher is the breed of cow and they raise this cow in Galicia which is a northern western part of Spain and it's absolutely gorgeous so today it's all about this cut we're not gonna do anything special we're just gonna do it right so we're gonna season it with a little bit of salt and smoke it so I'm gonna use my own salt and modeled salt is salt that is has a thickener shape it's made out of pyramids so the crystal of the modeled salt is shaped in pyramid style and you might think that it's a little bit overdone to use a salt like that but the reason why I like using salt like this on a stick is that these pyramids they they melt away so if you get one of these crystals on the beef it will melt and spread out where if you use rock salt it will stay in the same place because of the thickness of the steak you can't really have too much salt on the outside now we're gonna start off by smoking this cut of beef and the reason that we want to do that is because we wanted to get to temperature slowly and we might as well add a little bit of smoke flavor to it I'm using some Hickory for smoking it and Hickory will produce a heavy smoke and that's a good thing because it will stand out against grilling mistake which will also provide a lot of flavor now I'm setting in the deflector plates and I'm putting in grill grates and a beautiful steak on top we're going to smoke this beautiful steak at 150 degrees Celsius which is 300 degrees Fahrenheit until it reaches a core temperature of 50 degrees Celsius while our steak is slowly getting up to temperature we want to make sure that we got the right temperature and we're not exceeding the temperature that we want to reach so I'm getting a reading of 25 degrees Celsius so we're halfway there now we started off with a cold steak so that's about right I want to flip the steak over just to make sure then we get an equal amount of heat on every side oh boy I'm already getting hungry [Music] so it's a little over fifty degrees Celsius we're taking it off the grill be careful you don't want it to fall off the bone at this moment now we're gonna change it up a little bit we're going to take out the deflector plates and we're going to put in this cast iron Halfmoon and that's gonna create a beautiful cross for the meat so we'll take out these grill grates take out these deflector plates with a little poke they're gonna Center the coals put in our half at a low position take a little bit of oil a piece of paper towel and now we're gonna give it some time to really heat up well it's blazing hot and we're going to add just a little bit of touch of Oh more and then we're gonna put the stick right on now we've got a nice bit of sear and we're going to take our steak off the grill content: [Music] we're producing incredible content we don't want you to miss it's free click Subscribe for mobile and email updates about great new videos so you can get the most out of your butcher box hey there i'm Yankel and today i'm going to show you how to grill for a crowd there are a couple of really important things to remember first of all you need to have fun especially if you're not getting paid to do it so I'm gonna show you how to do that with some of my pro tips number one do as much prep as possible before you get started pro tip 2 easy to cook quick cooking cuts of beef and I'm gonna use boneless chicken thighs today as well because they are awesome on the grill and cook really fast pro tip number 3 I'm going to use sides that go really well on the grill and pro tip number 4 wrap the whole thing up with a really easy quick delicious dessert I've got a terrific menu plan for you today first thing we're gonna do is a flank steak marinated in my all-time favorite beef marinade then we're gonna do boneless skinless chicken thighs with a delicious citrus marinade we're gonna do a smoky summery herb potato salad with bacon some grilled vegetables with aged balsamic and we're gonna wrap the whole thing up with a absolutely amazing grilled peach shortbread time to light the grill coat tip number 34 they don't go in order don't worry start with the things that take the longest first so I'm going to light the grill and then we're going to move on to getting the potatoes going potatoes are obviously something you can do inside on your stove I'm lucky enough to have an extra grill nearby so I'm going in remember when you're doing potatoes for mashed potato or potato salad start your potatoes in cold water [Music] heavily salted water thank and water when it comes to boiling water on your grill do it the way you would do it on a stove medium to high heat when you add your ingredients turn the heat all the way up takes a little while longer but we have the time because we're gonna plan the rest of the party right now we're gonna marinate our proteins right now I'm using my two favorite marinades both of which are in the butcher box kitchen handbook you don't have a copy yet go get a copy we're gonna start with the beef marinade that's real easy I've got minced garlic lime zest fresh chopped cilantro and of course I'm using some beautiful salt and olive cabron cosas extra virgin olive oil we just want enough olive oil to make a paste so I start with a little bit give it a quick stir [Music] when you think about a marinade you have all these amazing ingredients that are using to flavor the beef how do you tie it all together you have to choose an excellent olive oil that really adds the final element all right beef marinade is done now we're gonna do the chicken marinade it's a citrus based marinade so I'm using orange peel and all lemon again with the peel some onion fresh minced garlic chopped thyme chopped rosemary we're gonna give that a quick pulse and then we're gonna slowly add some olive oil to bring it together we want a paste not soup beautiful I like to be very precise with my seasoning so I'm going to season all the meat first before I add the marinade beautiful butcher box flank steaks time to marinate my beef [Music] time for the chicken [Music] after many years of burning myself I realized safety first we're gonna get our grill ready to grill some vegetables so my coals are hot I'm gonna spread out the rest of the coals for the vegetables we want one even surface of coals I let my coals in the chimney they got really hot I add them to unlit coals they're gonna meet and get really hot but while that's happening we're gonna grill our vegetables so we have a medium heat to grill our vegetables and then a super high heat to grill our meat pro tip number 996 we're gonna put our grill grate on and let that heat up so I've got whole years of corn and I've cleaned the silk from the inside replace the husk and soak them in water we're gonna put them directly on the coals [Music] there's a power washer out there but we still have to grill our vegetables what are you gonna do salt and pepper olive oil not too much oil because we don't want it to flare up [Music] [Applause] [Music] a pro tip when it comes to grilling vegetables is keep them in as large pieces as possible that makes it really easy to grill so onions I cut into three pieces not more than that everything else I'm leaving whole will cut it up afterwards [Music] well it's still the apocalypse next door but we don't care about that because we have a delicious summery potato salad to make champagne vinegar Dijon mustard whole-grain mustard mayonnaise just some good old-fashioned kosher salt [Music] dill parsley Paragon [Music] I like to peel the charred skin off of peppers it can taste a little bit bitter to eat you still have all that grilled smoked flavor inside the pepper [Music] [Applause] I'm going to dress the vegetables with some traditional balsamic which is aged 18 years this is from salt and olive in Cambridge it is phenomenal no matter what you do this makes it taste way better it's perfect every time smoky grilled sweet from the vegetables sweet from the balsamic vinegar a little bit of acidity at the end there's gonna wow your guests all right it's time to grill the meat and I'm gonna set up two zones which is what I like when I'm cooking beef I'm gonna sear it on the hot zone finish it on the cool zone and I've actually thrown a couple of wood chips onto the coals those are gonna help smoke the beef so we're gonna close the grill up for a few minutes while we grow [Music] we're gonna close up the grill for about a minute before we do our first quarter turn closing it back up for one more minute one more minute on the hot side then we're going to move them to the cool side to finish the cooking now that I've cleared up my hot zone I'm putting the chicken down we're gonna let the chicken go for a couple of minutes before we turn it and we're gonna let the steaks finish we're gonna close up the grill so that it smokes nicely perfect medium-rare don't forget you got to let your steaks rest at least 10 minutes that'll make the inside beautifully red and reserved all the juices now we're going to flip our chicken and remove them to the cooler part chicken is all set we're gonna pull it off clean the grill off and then we're gonna grill our peaches for dessert oh yeah we're gonna let those rest for about 2 or 3 more minutes meanwhile let's get our peaches on the grill got these beautiful yellow peaches they're gonna go flesh side down as soon as the peaches have a little bit of color on them I'm going to slice them up throw in a bowl and hit them with a little bit of sugar [Music] Peach's have just a bit of color time to pull them off and slice them remember when you're slicing into your flank steak it'll be absolutely delicious and tender if you cut it properly there's a very distinct grain running through the steak and you want to cut against that it's a long piece of meat so I'm gonna cut it in half before I turn it and slice against the grain nice thin slices will make it extra tender [Music] that was awesome I'm surrounded by information subscribe to our YouTube channel watch more awesome recipe content full recipe in the link below i'm Yankel see in the next one

title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: How to Cook a Steak in the Oven
content: you know sometimes the weather doesn't cooperate with grilling a steak outdoors but that's okay because there's a lot of great ways to cook a steak indoors one way is to use your oven broiler now you want to use the broiler element because when you're cooking a steak searing is the most important thing and the broiler element is the only place where you're going to get a hot enough temperature where you're going to get the good searing so the first thing we're going to do is preheat the oven broiler on high then we want to adjust the top rack so that the element will be three to four inches away from our food that's what's going to give us that great sear next we're going to prepare the steaks after we've fully thawed them we want to blot them dry with a clean paper towel this is going to help our oil and seasoning stick to the steaks I like to use one of our Omaha steak seasoning blends because I find it really enhances the flavor of our steaks once we prepared the steaks we're going to put them on a pan and place them in the broiler I like to cover my pan with foil because it makes the cleanup a lot easier afterwards now the steaks are in the oven the age-old question is how long do we cook them for well I like my steaks medium rare so I'm just going to refer to the Omaha Steaks cooking chart these steaks are an inch and a quarter thick so it tells me to cook them eight minutes on the first side and then flip them over and cook them for six minutes on the second side this is going to give me that perfect medium-rare as always I'm gonna let these steaks rest for five minutes before serving this allows the juices to redistribute so I'll have a perfect steak
