content: hi I'm Rob Barrett and you're watching cooking for dads today we're gonna make kabobs they're awesome and a lot of fun a great thing to do in the summer let's go get our stuff you're gonna need some chicken breasts some steak I definitely recommend getting top sirloin filet or a flank steak don't get tip steak or anything like that for a kabob get some 16 to 20 count shrimp they're perfect for your Bob's to the right size it tastes awesome get some lemons get some coconut milk get some curry powder get some salt and pepper and if you want extra credit get some coriander seed we're gonna make two kind of kebabs today the easiest possible kind and then a relatively complicated one I usually try to keep my recipes to things that you would have around the house normally but we're gonna make an exception because this is so good that's the beef stew tell you what I'm talking about the first one we're gonna do is lemon juice but we're gonna get our meat ready so we're gonna cut our meat into strips and then into cubes I kind of like to keep the cubes small they're just easier to eat and they cook faster so you don't have to wait as long so cut your chicken into strips and then into small cubes put those on the kabob people say you should soak your kabobs and water and you can do that my seam mine tend to burn up either way so these I did not soak in so they'll kind of get burned on the edges but it's not the biggest deal in the world there's our chicken you'll put these on the plate here's our shrimp try to handle all the raw meat at one time then wash your hands now this first recipe it's not really even a recipe I did a bunch of experiments and found out that lemon juice and butter work on almost anything they're super good here's our steak a top sirloin we're gonna cut this in strips put that on skewers so here our chicken shrimp and beef kebabs we're gonna hit them with salt and pepper both sides our flavor magnifiers if you will thanks to chef in for our pepper grinder I'm using coarse kosher salt because it's the best now all we're gonna do is squeeze fresh lemon juice on them and let them sit for as long as possible the lemon juice actually starts to cook the meat ahead of time so don't let it be like overnight but three four hours it's gonna taste amazing then we're gonna brush it with butter when we put it on the grill get lots of juice right on them don't worry about the seeds you're not gonna cook those cover these put them in the fridge and let them sit for like an hour 20 minutes is okay but try to get like an hour to light your grill scrub it wipe it oil it let your grill get hot enough so you can't really keep your hand over it for more than a second put on your kebabs you want to hear a sizzle brush to each with butter let me flare it up a little don't worry about it that's all good all these meats cook at different speeds that's why I put them on separate kebabs because the shrimp is gonna get done first and then the beef and then the chicken you want chicken cooked all the way through you want beef kind of pink on the inside the shrimp cooks like this about a minute aside for the shrimp two or three minutes aside for the beef and probably four minutes aside for the chicken the shrimp are turning red we're gonna flip them over very nice check our beef give that in another minute I know you think this recipe is too simple to be good but trust me it really is tasty and you flip them get the other sides of butter here flipping over the beef oh yeah hit that with butter I love cooking kabobs because I think it's the most basic cooking method that's probably the first thing that cavemen did it stick meat fire good you know it doesn't get any simpler than that the Minnesota State Fair we call it well we put everything on a stick so that's a whole different story but kabobs are just they're just instinctual these shrimp are firm and read all the way through we're pulling them off I'm gonna flip over our chicken very nice brush that with butter these beef cubes are done you can kind of see in the middle there that's kind of pink all right we're gonna pull that off those are done give this chicken one more minute you lose your chicken frames up so it doesn't push it all it is done pull it off you don't want to overcook your chicken okay there's the easy one salt pepper fresh lemon juice and butter these are super good we're gonna make the more complicated ones next but first viewer male yeah they're cooking for dads why do you always say to use coarse kosher salt wall-e's lodge from youtubers so we asked morton salt and then the crack growth back morning kosher salt is a coarse flake salt chefs and food enthusiasts use kosher salt if you like the coarse grain it's easier to get the right pinch something it has a cleaner crisp flavor morning table salt normal salt that has finer cubic sake crystals it also has a free-flow agent that ensures when it rains it pours both iodized and non-iodized table salt are available both kosher and table salt are certified as kosher however kosher salt got us things because is the salt used in the culturing process for meat and poultry the coaching process from eating poultry is under rabbinical supervision and the rabbi's require that of course salt be used there you have it Wally good luck with that send it in for the more complicated one we're gonna make what's called the satay this is actually an Asian kebab it is so good that it's worth going through this F extra effort we are going to take half a can of coconut milk one spoonful of salt one spoonful of sugar two spoonfuls of curry powder some fresh ground pepper and for extra credit get some coriander seeds and crush them up this is completely optional but it's a super good just get about half a spoonful pour them in crush them down they smell just like amazingly good pour that in stir that up this is our marinade for our satay and is really good into that put your beef chicken and shrimp or all the above this really works great with beef stir that up that smells incredible okay put this in the fridge cover it and let it sit for as long as possible even 20 minutes is good or if you can do 3 or 4 hours you're gonna be happy campers and I'll take your various meats and put them on kebabs it gets a little messy but once again it'll be worth it if you want something that has a little different look leave your meat and strips and kind of weave your skewer back and forth into it a lot of restaurants serve satay this way when you're done you'll need to wash up light it scrub it wipe it oil it put on your kabobs so your shrimps gonna cook about a minute aside your beef about two to three minutes aside and the chicken about four to five minutes aside depending on how big your chunks are I keep my chunks pretty small so they cook fast because I don't like to wait for my food flip over our shrimp smooth whoa smoothly flip over our beef a shrimp is firm and red on both sides nicely done take that off our beef is done we're gonna turn over our chicken our chicken is done and we are done with this satay you want to serve it with the peanut sauce either you can buy a premade one there are lots of different kinds this one's really good it's a Sanji peanut sauce or Lian Chin's peanut sauce or you can make your own right here on the grill get your pan small pan use the other half of your coconut milk three spoonfuls of sugar three spoonfuls of peanut butter you smooth if you can these are mandatory things two spoonfuls of fish sauce fish sauce you can give them the Asian part of your market this is Thai curry paste you're gonna do one spoonful of Thai red curry or Panang curry spelt like that put that in for super extra pair that you want some tamarind paste about a spoonful this is really optional you're gonna have to go to an Asian grocery store to get that but it really adds a super taste to the finished product okay you're gonna take this and put this on your grill better keep your your handle off to the side you're just gonna combine all the stuff if you wanna make the sauce over the stove that's cool too this just keeps your house from getting heated up let it simmer for a couple minutes stirring and pour it into a little side dish you're done so there you have it the simple kabob just lemon and butter salt and pepper and the more complicated but super worth it satay with a coconut milk and then the peanut sauce and Rob Barrett this is cooking for dads cook well it's worth it mmm that is worth it

title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: The Perfect Steak | How to light your Charcoal Grill the Right Way
content: hey thanks for watching I'm Sebastian and today we're going to talk about how to light your grill the right way the question we get a lot from our customers is how to light the charcoal how to light the grill you know it seems a lot of people are doing it wrong you know they buy this like lighter fluid and they just put it on the charcoal the throw match and they walk away and they expect magic to happen and the charcoal to light but it's really not the way to do it the golden rule of lighting charcoal is to light it from the bottom up you really want to get your your fire starter under your charcoal light it and put the charcoal on top and let the flame the fire work its way from the bottom up here are some of my favorite ways to light charcoal one of the most popular tools to light a fire is a chimney starter fill your chimney starter with charcoal and then place a fire starter like newspaper or four fire starter under your chimney light it and place the chimney on top my personal favorite to light charcoal just directly in the ground fill your grill with charcoal and leave an empty spot in the middle that's where you want to place your fire starter light your fire starter and then carefully built a charcoal pyramid on top of your growing fire with both of these methods of lighting the charcoal your fire will be ready in 15 to 20 minutes enough time to get a drink and to prepare your food we have a special surprise for you today we're going to cook one of my favorite cuts of meat skirt steak worse they call it in Miami and tyranian as you can see and Daniel is laced with fat which is going to give it a really great juicy tasting steak and we're going to sear over the hot charcoal just a few minutes on each side and we're going to eat it let's go [Music] [Applause] [Music] [Applause] [Music] Wow this turnout amazing look at the color on this and the crust so juicy oh I just love skirt steak it has the best flavor well folks that's the end of our episode for today thank you so much for watching if you liked it subscribe to our Channel and share it with your friends and see you next week thank you [Music]

title: How to Grill Steak

content: hi I'm Micah and you know recently I was in Canada and visiting with some family and my brother-in-law has fancy whiz-bang barbecue with a smoking attachments to it so we smoked pretty much everything while we were there we smoked the pork we smoked chicken we smoked beef I think the only thing we didn't smoke was some fish but now I'm home in Australia and I wanted to give it a go unfortunately I don't have the whiz-bang barbecue that my brother-in-law has so I decided that that I would go to my local local barbecue shop and have a look and see what they have so looking around I found that they have this barbecue chef stainless steel smoker box so I picked one of those up for about 20 bucks and this smoking wood chip blamed so I picked this up as well now I haven't done this before so you guys are along for the ride and just cleaning my barbecue so I'll take you through some of the steps that I've done so as you can see I've just got your basic your basic barbecue just four burner gas barbecue now what I've done is I've taken a couple of handful handfuls of the woodchips and I'm just soaking them in water for well pretty much for as long as possible and wood chips all over my hands and what I'm also doing is one of the things we tried in Canada was brining so I've had a look and I found a brining recipe for steak so I've just got some porterhouse or strict States as they call them in North America and I've got some bourbon some honey salt and rough chopped garlic and water I'm going to leave them in there for probably for a couple of hours then I'm gonna take them out rinse them off and set everything up mmm give this smoking gig ago so yeah come back in a sec so I've got most of the preparation done I just want to sort of give you a look at what the setup looks like so as you can see I've got the smoker set up here and really it's just a stainless steel metal box with with holes in it and then over here what I've got is I've got a just a pan of water now what I understand is that when you're smoking a meat can sometimes dry out even though I'm brining the meat so I just wanted to have a pan of water in there just to keep the humidity up a bit now I haven't done this before as I mentioned and not really working off a recipe except for the for the brine recipe so with regards to how we're going to cook this the plan is to slow smoke the meat probably I don't know I'm gonna have to I'm gonna have to guess but possibly for up to 30 minutes at on a low indirect heat and then the idea is what I'm gonna try is I'm gonna take that meat off I'm gonna crank the barbecue up as high as I can I'm gonna put some salt on the meat and just barbecue it like I normally would which is pile of salt on there for a little bit and then just sort of brush it off just before I'm going to I'm gonna grill it so we'll give that a go and when I'm ready to to cook then I'll bring you along for the journey I'll see you how we go okay so the steaks have been smoking for I guess probably about an hour maybe so here they are here I did some fish with them as well as you can see so now what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna fire up the grill and we're going to cook them as I would normally cook a steak so fairly hot grill let it get hot and I'm gonna throw some olive oil on there and grill them up and see what they taste like right okay so we've cooked all the steaks and I'm just gonna just take a little chunk here hasn't rested yet but let's just see Wow mmm very nice can really taste the brine coming out and there's a hint of smoke so it's really quite nice so I'll put a I'll put a link to the recipe on my web page on my blog page and I'll put the link in the comments below so until next time happy grilling

title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: Pan-Grilling Thin Steaks : Steak Recipes
content: [Music] good afternoon I'm chef Jackson lamb here at the hospitality Learning Center at MSU Denver today I'd like to review how to pan grill thin steaks when it comes to steaks most people don't butcher their own steaks at all they go to their local supermarket either they're working with the butcher that's there or the steaks are already pre-cut and they're in the meat section grab and go so what I've got today are very thin steaks okay this is not unusual from what we're going to see in the butcher department and what we're going to do is we're going to pan sear these and right after we season them with salt pepper and a little olive oil so my pan is getting nice and hot so what I'd like to do now is I'm going to season these and as we put a little bit of olive oil on here I'm going to do that because that's going to allow my steak to run around the inside of the pan we're going to go ahead and we're going to take a little salt we're going to take a little pepper very good but let's season both sides so we're going to flip these over slightly there we go a little bit more olive oil a little bit more salt and a little bit more pepper and we are ready to go so ladies and gentlemen our steaks are seasoned I'm getting ready to go into a hot pan but first pan sear a thin steak why would you want a thin steak a lot of people like a big fat juicy steak but when you have a thin steak like this multiple uses you can make yourself a steak sandwich steak and eggs you can use these steak medallions over the top of a salad you can make a Philadelphia cheesesteak sandwich you could use these for steak fajitas so a thin steak is just as valuable and versatile as a big steak so let's get them cooking so going to go ahead and take my we'll take our medallions we're going to put these right into the pan here obviously the pan is pretty hot we're getting some response right away from the heat and again we're going to let those sit for just about 30 seconds we're going to keep them moving it's harder on a thin steak to get a rare medium rare or medium doneness typically since the steak is thin we're going to be medium to medium well so bear that in mind when you're doing this at home once we have our steaks in the pan we want to leave them alone for about a minute or a minute and a half the fact that they're thin they're going to cook a lot faster than a thick steak so I'm ready to flip these over right now and as I flip this you can see some great color we see the sear on the meat we've got a little carmelization there we're going to continue to let these go for only another minute and we'll be done again I mention the applications earlier steak fajitas steak and eggs steak sandwich Philadelphia cheese sandwich your choice great product thin steak quick to cook hey I'm Jackson lamb thanks for watching you [Music]

title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: How to Cook Pork Steak
content: hello everyone today I will show you how to cook pork steak this is a Filipino dish we're in pork chops are cut in soy sauce onion and lemon and here are the ingredients we will be using pork chops for this recipe yellow onion soy sauce a piece of lemon and crushed garlic will also use cooking oil ground black pepper sugar and beef or pork broth and here is the complete list of the ingredients that I just mentioned let's start by marinating the pork I'm just gonna grab a resealable bag such as a ziplock bag and put all the pork chops in it just make sure that a bag is large enough to accommodate all the pork chop now we will pour the soy sauce into the bag you can use either dark soy sauce or light soy sauce it really depends on your preference I'm also gonna squeeze a piece of lemon in here and I'm gonna shake the bag just to mix all the ingredients together next we'll seal the bag but before we do that just make sure to push most of the air out before sealing it marinate the pork chop for at least one hour once done we just need to drain the excess marinade and set it aside we'll be using it later on at this point we need to pan fry the pork chops I'm just gonna spray some cooking oil on a pan that I already heated and let's just wait until the oil heats up and once the oil heats up that means it's time for us to put the pork chops into the pan one by one we need to pan fry one side of the pork chop for one and a half minutes we're just trying to partially cook the pork chop until it grounds a bit and afterwards we will turn this over to do the same thing on the other side we will also be pan frying the other side for one and a half minutes once done we'll just take the pork chops out of the pan and set it aside now it's time to saute the garlic and onion let's start by pouring oil on the pan wait for it to heat up a bit and then add the garlic we are using crushed garlic in this recipe you can also use chopped garlic if you want well cook the garlic for around 15 seconds and then we will be adding half of the onions we'll be saving the other half for later let's continue to saute the garlic and onion until the onion starts to soften now it's time to deglaze the pan I'm just gonna pour some beef broth to deglaze it and then we'll be scraping this gently using our bamboo spoon there you go and then I'll just pour the remaining marinade this is the soy sauce and lemon mixture that we use initially to marinate the pork chops in let it boil and then put the pork chops back in here again piece by piece we'll need to cook the pork chops longer until it becomes tender so what I need to do here is put everything all together and then we will be covering the pan and adjust a heat to medium and continue to cook the pork chops for 20 minutes after 20 minutes the pork chops are partially cooked now we need to turn it over to cook the other side doing this will make the porkchops more tender it will also balance the color if you'll notice the site cooked in soy sauce is darker than the opposite side cooking the lighter side in soy sauce will make the color uniform I'm going to add more broth this is just to make sure that the sauce does not dry up while we're cooking I'm also going to cover the pot again and cook this for 18 minutes and after 80 minutes were almost ready it's time to season our pork chops we'll put a bit of sugar here and some ground black pepper here's the sugar and a ground black pepper and we're not going to use any salt for this dish because the soy sauce is already salty if you want to add salt just make sure to taste the sauce first and see if it's really needed just make sure that all the ingredients are well blended and right now it's time to add the last ingredient I'm referring to the remaining onions it's good to have more onions in your pork stay so that'll be really tasty I'll just spread it on the pan and after this we'll just cover it and cook for eight minutes more now our pork steak is ready it's time to transfer it to a serving plate and serve it with warm white rice thank you for watching this video if you liked it don't forget to hit like and share on the video below I am also inviting you to subscribe to our YouTube channel see you next time on our next video

title: How to Grill Steak
original_title: How to Make Grilled Asian Skirt Steak
content: this is how you make grilled Asian skirt steak start by making the marinade add the olive oil soy sauce freshly squeezed lime juice brown sugar green onions garlic cloves cumin and red pepper flakes to a blender or food processor process the ingredients until you get a smooth liquid now cut the skirt steak into 8 pieces and add them to a resealable plastic bag pour in the marinade close the bag and give it a shake to cover all the meat with the marinade leave in the fridge for a minimum of three hours or overnight if you want remember to turn the bag every now and then while the meat marinades now remove the steaks from the marinade and grill or broil them turning them over once while they cook adjust the cooking time depending on how you like your steak done let the steaks rest for five minutes this will help them stay more juicy slice them across the grain and serve
